Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Great to see the sensors channel. I am working with a client that would like to know when a roller on a conveyor is turning (to detect product movement). They would like to know speed, but state may suffice. The client suggested an encoder which I am working with P+F on, but these require PLC configuration, which I am not familiar with. 

Curious if anyone has any suggestions. I thought about getting some kind of small gear that could be mounted to the roller and they use a photo eye to detect movement/speed. Something that output a current of voltage signal would be preferred. Thoughts?

I think you could use a single toothed gear that passes a photo-eye every revolution (basically the index channel on an encoder) and maybe pair that with a physical, delay-off timer so that the signal stays high for the amount of time a revolution should take and gets re-triggered every cycle.

Author: .leehunt
Content: What is the general POV on IO-Link and IO-Link wireless?  I can see the tech being valuable for OEM's and certain manufacturing processes but was wondering if large controls vendors are adopting the standard or developing their own competing systems.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I think long term, it's going to be a big deal. Although it's been around for a few decades, it's still in its infancy for being used in a controls cabinet.

It needs a bit of standardization and manufacturers need to make it easier to get all the non-process data into your PLC. I think that will come, a lot of vendors already have function blocks for AB, it will just take time for that to make its way to the other PLCs.

A few downsides:
- It's a star topology, you cant daisy-chain sensors. This makes sense for standard analog sensors but not for a digital, sensor. No reason a bus couldn't be have been designed, but IO-Link was originally created for sensor manufacturers to update their settings on their sensors so a base sensor (example proximity sensor) could be tuned to different setting and then be different SKUs
- It's not built in to any PLCs

I think a different sensor bus technology could come along and replace these things. Ideally it would be an open standard and also specify things like standardized connectors (style and pinout) so that we can get closer to having the "USB of Industrial devices"

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Apologies for the slow response. There are a number of wireless sensors available that will provide reliability data. It all depends on the use case. The intent of the sensors is to enhance reliability which can be accomplished in several ways. 

If all you want is the data, there are many that will accomplish this. I am most familiar with National Instruments and Erbessd. The later has a number of different sensors that integrate into their visualization package.

The next level uses sensors that incorporate machine learning. These are connected to a cloud backend that provide visualization and alerts for asset health issues. Proaxion, Nikola Labs and Symphony Industrial AI all have good technology. Symphony has the most developed asset models along with the ability to include process data for process health, as well.

There are new technologies on the market that use ML at the edge. Rather than send a bunch of data for analysis, the bulk of it is done at the edge with a backend ML/AI performing additional analysis. The cloud also provides alerts and visualization. I am quite familiar with VIE Technologies for this.

Wireless vibration has become quite popular because it eliminates the need for a vibration technician to spend 20 hours per week gather and analyzing data. The sensors do the bulk of the work which frees up the technician to perform higher value work. Hope this helps.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
One other thing to consider is that serial I/O will block if the output buffer is full, which doesn't take much (it's quite tiny).  You can however check the output buffer status and skip or queue a write if its full.

When dealing with stuff like Arduinos, you find you have to do a lot more work managing state than you do with higher level abstractions/languages.  And error handling can be a real challenge, but if you want it to be robust and reliable it ends up being a sizable percentage of the actual code.

Arduinos are notorious for  s**ting the bed due to serial buffer overflows. It's been a plaguing issue for years. It most often occurs in 2 ways.
1. You're sending Serial.print() statements too quickly. You should ALWAYS be using a non-blocking timing routine for serial prints. A loop on even a crummy, Arduino Uno can still be blazingly fast compared to most PLCs (<1-2 microseconds depending on your code). Usually this acutally leads to your serial monitor on your computer crashing and not the arduino though.
2. You're doing Serial.print()s and you unplug the USB cable. You'd think Arduino would be smart enough to not try to send data over the UART when it's unplugged, but it isn't. Depending on your publish rate, this will eventually cause you to overflow the print buffer and crash the program in fun and exciting ways.

In general, be cautious with Serial prints, they're extremely useful and pretty much the only way to debug an arduino program until you move into realm of debuggers like J-Links but they're a double edged sword. They're very slow and will interfere with the timing of your program.

Author: benveenema
Content: Also, Arduino example sketches are usually terrible. They use blocking code, like delay(), exorbitant Serial.print()s, and almost never use good abstraction or error handling practices. It's a good way to see how to interact with a peripheral or library, but copy-pasting the loop() code into your application is probably not going to work long term.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I like this, and think it might be the perfect staring point for a person or team transition from PLC centric controls programming to Arduino/Embedded, but it carries a lot of PLC/ladder ideas into the Arduino/C++ world that aren't necessary or not ideal.

- Adding BIT/INT/FLOAT to the end of variable name. This is 100% unneeded in a proper IDE (aka, not Arduino IDE) as your editor should tell you what type it is. Worse than that, what if I decide I need to change an INT to a FLOAT? Now I have to update the variable name everywhere it's used? Sure you can use find&replace, but what if you forget or were "just testing it" and then get distracted and move on to something else.

- I love that the author recommends containers and separate files instead of one, big, file, but the method for implementing it is very simplistic and isn't true abstraction. It has a dangerous illusion of local variables, but actually requires way to many globals. Instead of setting bits in a container or class, use a functional interface. For example instead of pistonStartBIT, use Piston.Start() (or Piston_Start() if you aren't comfortable with C++ class syntax). True abstraction is a little more complicated than the authors method and can be intimidating for people new to text-based, object oriented languages, but IMHO, it's the only way to write large, robust controls programs.

I really like this article and I'm really glad someone put something like this out there. It has me thinking, I should put out my own standards if I'm so damn opinionated about it...

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
PA and DP are same PROFIBUS protocol, but different physical implementations.  DP is RS485 and PA is MBP.  MBP provides power over the bus safely.  This satisfies requirements in process industries.  PA and DP can adapted with segment couplers.  This is not an uncommon use case.  PI and Siemens have documentation.

PA is far less common than DP.  Regardless, if you can selectively deploy PROFINET in parallel to the existing PROFIBUS infrastructure, it will open up a ton of options.  Figure out what is there because it must be there (e.g., compliance, safety) vs what doesn't have to be there (e.g., tradition).

Most IO-Link Master products focus on IP67 and Ethernet-based fieldbuses.  Because IO-Link came out well into the PROFINET era, PROFIBUS support is somewhat limited.  Check out Balluff or Siemens.  Order soon.  The lead times on this are insane right now.  I believe I've only seen one IFM product with this.  All the more reason to use PROFINET where possible.

As for the hazardous requirement, you might have to "roll your own" with enclosures for IP20 units.  I would recommend reaching out to an application engineer at one of the major IO-Link players (e.g., IFM, Balluff, P+F) with your requirements for your industry.  They should have reference architectures for your industry.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Yeah, this has been a common argument for years against any sort of transition.  This is usually a symptom of the fact that the company doesn't have any proficiency in anything but 4-20mA communications, so putting something different in can be intimidating.  I've seen this with everything from Modbus to Ethernet (seriously dating myself).  Your best bet is to not approach this from a technology standpoint, but from a change management perspective.  Start by describing how awesome their life would be if they made the change, then get the first win.  This may need to  be small, and you may need to essentially give it away to get it in there, but your goal is to put it side by side with the old tech and get them to see the difference and the fact that it will be easy to use.  After that, get the person, or people, from the plant to help you to get that solution into other areas.  Just an FYI, if your blocker (the guy that just doesn't want to make the change) is in a serious place of power, then it will be difficult.  The easiest transitions always have a higher placed person that is receptive to change.

As for benefits, safety is always a big one, especially in the harsher applications (oil and gas).  Newer technologies can mean more reliable signals, and less requirements for maintenance, which means less time for the tech to be in a potentially hazardous area.  Just be ready for the pushback that the thing that is out there is tried and tested and the new tech isn't.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Depends on the media.  If the media is conductive, then a simple conductivity sensor will work.  Run a few experiments to determine the conductivity level of various media concentrations, and you should be good as long as you do not change media.  If not then you are looking at a turbidity or suspended solids measurement, done optically or with ultrasonics.  For turbidity, it will give you a set NTU/FTU reading, for suspended solids, you'll need to do some testing to determine the attenuation for the various media concentration levels.  Conductivity is the easiest and cheapest (~$100 - $1000), suspended solids less so, and turbidity sensors are fairly expensive (~$5k - $10k).  All of them can be pipe or tank mounted.

What is your media?  What is your process?

Content:
In my experience, I would recommend against using microcontroller in production scenenarios (except when you really know what you are doing and have enough time).
Just reading out data from I/Os can get quite difficult as you have to worry about timing (when to send messages, when to read data). You can start using an RTOS, but that does not fully address all issues.

Author: jermuk
Content: Also I would not recommend consumer hardware like the raspberry pi for anything critical. The electronics behind it are good enough for the IT World, but a raspberry pi will need maintenance around every 2 years, which is not what OT typically loves. Especially the SD card situation (SD cards are not designed for continuous read/writes. Even industrial SD cards don't come near the usual reliability required for OT)

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm not familiar with that specific IO-Link Master or its web configuration.  For a starter kit, it would be odd that they weren't preloaded to work out of the box.  Perhaps you may need to assign a device to each port.

IO-Link sensors and actuators have IODD files to define the payload and meta data.  These get loaded into the Master.  They can obtained from the OEM's site or PI's site.  Alternatively, these can be manually programmed based off an IODD document.  Once these definitions are present, it should possible to assign the ports of the Master to a specific IO-Link Device.  From a PLC or application perspective, some brands even maintain libraries (e.g., Studio 5000 AOI, TIA Portal FB, Ignition) that parse and build out tag structures according to the IODD.

Looking through the Comtrol documentation, it looks like the IODD files need to loaded into their IOLM client.

PI / IO-LInk Consortium:  IODD Database
https://io-link.com/en/IODDfinder/IODDfinder.php

Comtrol Guides:
https://comtrol.com/io-link-master-gateways/io-link-competency-center/load-iodd-files-onto-the-io-link-master-to-streamline-io-link-device-configuration
https://downloads.comtrol.com/dr-8-eip-t/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Try port TCP 4840 (w/o TLS) or TCP 4843 (w/ TLS).  These are the official OPC UA ports.  TCP 49320 is what Kepware uses by default for some reason.  It's not registered with IANA.

Check out the tutorial with UaExpert around page 20:
https://files.pepperl-fuchs.com/webcat/navi/productInfo/doct/tdoct8129__usa.pdf?v=20220525202151

I demo'd the Comtrol stuff a few years ago.  I liked the fact that it had OPC UA on board, but the rest of the product was kind of clunky.  I didn't like how IP addresses were managed and I also noticed that the web interface was slow.  Ironically, other manufacturers had white labeled some Comtrol models and the implementation was better.  Some of the early IFM IP20 models were physically identical, but used different browser-based software to configure.

For some reason, IO-Link tends to work better over a fieldbus with a PLC as the gateway than it does with an IIoT protocol.  There is less support for applications than PLCs.  The one exception appears to be IFM with what they built out for Ignition.  I've yet to try this though.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: To be fair it depends....im a big fan of ethercat, so using an ethercat based plc with io link blocks and scanning the network automatically populates my PLC variable list with all IO detected. I think thats a lot easier than having to plug in multiple wires into an IO block, and then having to map variables...the main cost difference will come down to setup/integration time, lots of sensors = lots of wiring + maintenance....but i cant see how adding io link would be cheaper than a discrete sensor with pnp/npn wiring.....you need specialized io blocks + connectors etc...

Author: trentc
Content: Which plc are you referring to? My experience is that the process data requires the addition of the IODD into the configuration software or needs to be decoded with function blocks or custom code based on the sensor type. This added complexity,for the lay person that is used to traditional io, presents an extra layer of effort. I‚Äôm fully on board with Ethercat and IOLink, it‚Äôs my first choice, but my experience is that its not usually as simple as mapping a single digital input. And the wiring time savings you are referring to is really just a difference in terminals vs connector based IO (m8/m12), not iolink itself, with the exception being non binary sensors like analog, where the wiring and cabling of traditional methods being very time consuming. You are correct, implementing IOLink for only discrete sensors would cost more because of the master, and slight increase in sensor, but the wiring and connectors are there same. However, if you look at analog, or position, or measurement sensors, IOLink can often be easier to implement, less wiring, cheaper cables, easier data mapping, data already in engineering units, and potentially cheaper than their analog equivalent solutions.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
You can mix and match sensors and masters, but the experience is far superior if you try to keep things within one brand.  The cross-vendor interoperability of IO-Link is defined by the IO Device Description (IODD).  You can use this with any IO-Link device.  Many people actually store the config on a PLC to "write" to the device.  This is very useful for replacing a failed sensor without needing to program it.

There are some offerings that go beyond the IO-Link spec.  For example, if you download IFM's "Start Up Package" for its masters supporting PROFINET, there are function blocks that can be imported into Siemens TIA Portal to specifically interface with IFM products.  It's like having a driver for the device.  This is in contrast of mapping in and out of a generic IODD structure exchanged over PROFINET.  Additionally, IFM's LR-Device or Moneo software will have libraries, configuration menus, photos, etc of their own sensors.  It's these libraries and applications are what make IO-Link useful as a tech IMO.

It would be nice to see more elegant cross-vendor integrations, but the spec only goes so far and it takes work to maintain those libraries.  At the end of the day, IO-Link is mostly field protocol that connects to devices over a standard M12 cable.  The compute on these devices is often more primitive than what is needed to support TCP/IP Ethernet.  There isn't much room for overhead in the protocol.  It has a simple object model.  The clients need to do most of the work to really make use of it.

Author: m_r_mccormick
Content:
I'd make a distinction between languages (Python2, Python3, Cython, etc), compilers/interpreters (CPython, Cython, Jython, IronPython, Micro/CircuitPython, etc), and frameworks/libraries which are compatible with a given compiler/interpreter. There is a many to many relationship between languages and compilers/interpreters, but much more limited compatibility between compilers/interpreters and frameworks/libraries. I've learned enough different languages to be comfortable in picking up any new language quickly and easily, but the time consuming part for me is learning the frameworks/libraries which are specific to a given compiler/interpreter. The issue I have with Jython is not its use of Python2, but rather how easily extensible it is since you (likely) have to extend it in a different language if a capability isn't natively provided. But, this depends on the use case, what you're trying to achieve, and available technical expertise.

I see two use cases/capability levels here: 1) Using scripting within the bounds of a device/service to interact with the device/service's API, and 2) being able to do basically whatever you want on the device. In the case of an IIoT edge device like the Shelly plug, Python/Jython would be acceptable for use case (1). But, being able to bring whatever capabilities you want via regular python libraries (or better yet containers) would offer much more capability for (2). On an edge device where I'm not expecting to do something cute like run ML, (1) is acceptable and (2) is a bonus. However, in the case of ignition for instance, having (2) is a way bigger deal because I think of ignition as an 'I can do anything' platform, and Jython (not specifically Python2) really limits capability.

On embedded devices without an OS (e.g., microcontroller), I don't think you can really deliver (2) with a great developer experience. So, expectations should be set appropriately for the hardware/firmware and ecosystem at hand.

Author: tibi_03551
Content: Hi guys, do you know a solution for a smart sensor which counts products on assembly lines and is able to send MQTT messages when counting (it has a programmable component), can be powered through Ethernet cable, no electrical cabinet needed, is cost effective needed and  is industry grade?  Custom solutions are welcome, i.e. combine a dummy sensor with a microcontroller?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Not aware of a smart sensor that does all of this.

With PoE as a requirement, the options are limited.  Groov RIO in a small panel is the only thing that comes to mind.  Beckhoff EtherCAT P Box is an IP67 option.  It will carry power over the bus, but would require an IoT bus coupler somewhere to convert to MQTT.  This might not be a problem if the bus will be scaled out for each coupler.

There are IP67 IFM IO-Link Masters that can be used with IO-Link devices or DI/DO.  Some models have an MQTT and REST interface.  With the hubs, they can scale out to a lot of I/O.  Only the master would need 24VDC and Ethernet, but all the sensors could be M12 runs.  They won't count products, but probably could can be configured to publish the rising edge with a timestamp.  You would need sophisticated client to make sense of and tally the messages.

It's worth mentioning that if the process is fast and really needs to reliable, it might be better off looking into a low cost PLC.  What might seem like higher cost to start with may scale quite well with low cost DI to proximity sensors and photoeyes.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Having worked with both HTTP and BLE separately, my first though was "how do you get one of the heaviest protocols to work over one of the most bandwidth-limited channels?" On looking at the linked material, I remembered that this is not *HTTP-over-BLE*. This is browser code, running on your smart phone, to control the BLE radio built-in to your smart phone to talk to other BLE devices near your smart phone. Results of this communication can be returned to the browser for further use in the app. Given that many smart phone apps are written in browser-based, cross-platform frameworks like Flutter, I'd guess that most of them interact with off-board BLE devices in this way.

If you are looking for ways to network a number of wireless sensors within your plant, you want to look at [BLE Mesh](https://www.bluetooth.com/learn-about-bluetooth/feature-enhancements/mesh/) technology. Since this is neither TCP nor HTTP based, however, you will need gateway devices to connect your sensor mesh to broader control or enterprise networks.

Author: sim_sam3
Content: wonderful feedback! thank you so much for sharing such great details.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
here is a precise discussion of the technology stack: 

"It's perhaps a misnomer to talk about HTTP over Bluetooth. That's not what's happening here. This is a three tier architecture, with very lightweight Bluetooth LE communication between (1) a Bluetooth device and a (2) dual technology Bluetooth and TCP/IP device, acting as a proxy, which then communicates the Bluetooth encoded request that it has configured within it, to a (3) remote HTTP server over TCP/IP."

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47511294/how-can-we-use-http-over-bluetooth-low-energy-ble

Author: donpancoe
Content: A quick read implies that using the standard [HTTP Proxy Service (HPS)](https://www.bluetooth.com/specifications/specs/http-proxy-service-1-0/) could be less labor-intensive than manually building point-to-point connections from each BLE sensor to whatever gateway device you are using. This seems similar to [6LoWPAN](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/what-is-6lowpan/) in that it *appears* to give each BLE or other constrained wireless device an IP address, while acknowledging that these constrained devices and networks are not suitable for full TCP/IP implementation. BLE has the "HPS Server" and 6LoWPAN has the "edge router" to bridge the gap. Not knowing your intended application, maybe this has utility, maybe not.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
A power meter will typically have a Modbus map, which tells you what value is in what register, and what it's format is.

So if I have 100 Identical Modbus devices, especially one like a power meter where there are a lot of signals. I can take a lot of time to map the first one.
But once you have that done, the second is really quick. So If I came to site with no work done before hand,  to connect to 10 devices, Day 1 might be all bout connect in. on Day 2 might be connecting to the fist unit, and creating the dashboards and graphics. Day 3 - I might get most of the other 9 all collecting data and displaying it and storing to the historian, and Day 4 might be doing soe tidying up and validating.


So if I have a modern device that can save time, it works really well on one Device, but as I increase devices that relative saving drops.

Also, I was proposing this where there is already a Platform( SCADA typically) that can already connect to a Modbus devices. I can publish to my UNS from the SCADA, essentially using it as a IIOT Gateway. If I have to go and get a platform the strategy might change.

I also like to have a power meter that I can look at the front and see what the value is, and use that for validation.

Author: _dyland

Honestly, For me, having ordered one early and gotten another maybe a year ago, it's a combination of price and UX. On price, I rarely want just one or two sensors and when we talk multiple SHARCs we get into competition with the Opto 22 Grov RIO... Which wins out with features and UX. 

Adding to the cost is the need for POE, one of the biggest constraints for so many things in manufacturing is the lack of controls networks (at all) let alone POE Switches on the plant floor. So while I would love to fix this on a macro level a product that doesn't offer an immediate solution has already segmented its market to those that have.

After the price, my experience setting these up hasn't been the promised two minute install. Maybe that's user error and maybe it's room for improvement in the setup and configuration workflow flow? 

After that, it's marketing, brand, trust, etc. while I know otherwise and deeply respect the engineering that went into it, it does "Feel" cheap compared to other industrial components.

A technical side of trust, with any component like this, is how to do mass firmware updates? Visibility and maintainability of a fleet of SHARCs?

Above all, from the outside, I see it as a marketing and fit problem more than anything. Why use the SHARC over an IO link adapter or a platform like IFM Moneo? 

Again, all of this is my opinion based on my observations from the sidelines. I could very well be wrong.
